newsitem.title: INDIA: India, Russia begin defence talks.
newsitem.headline: India, Russia begin defence talks.

text.p: Russian Defence Minister Igor Rodionov met Indian Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda on Tuesday amid reports that New Delhi was ready to pay $1.8 billion for 40 warplanes.

Rodionov, who arrived in the Indian capital on Monday, was expected to sign a defence cooperation agreement during his three-day visit, the first by a Russian defence minister to India, officials said.

Itar-Tass news agency said India had confirmed its intention to buy 40 multi-purpose Sukhoi Su-30 jets for a total of $1.8 billion. The Press Trust of India (PTI) said the deal was expected to figure in Rodionov's talks with Indian leaders.

But a Russian embassy official said the visiting minister was not expected to sign a warplane deal. "The visiting minister cannot sign the agreement on the sale of planes as that involves more than one organisation," the official said.
A spokesman for the Indian Defence Ministry said details of the talks were expected to be released later.
As the former Soviet Union's main non-communist ally, India was one of Moscow's biggest arms clients.
Russian President Boris Yeltsin visited India in January 1993, helping clinch a debt repayment pact covering money which New Delhi owed Moscow mainly for military purchases.
Relations soured again after the United States forced Moscow to cancel a $250 million sale of cryogenic rocket engines on the grounds they could be used to build missiles.
But Russian Foreign Minister Yevgeny Primakov's Indian visit last March helped revive relations.
During Primakov's visit, the two countries agreed to set up a "hotline" telephone link between New Delhi and Moscow for the leaders of the two countries to hold crisis talks.

PTI said agreements on the training of Indian military personnel and a new service-to-service exchange between the armed forces of the two countries were likely to be finalised during Rodionov's visit.
The news agency said India was also interested in buying MSTA-S self-propelled howitzers.
